item.title: Reuters reveals France’s Thales considers move for Atos cybersecurity arm BDS
item.dc:creator: Jaime-Lee Charles
item.description:
Reuters was first to report that French defense group Thales is working on a plan to buy the cybersecurity business of IT […]

The post Reuters reveals France’s Thales considers move for Atos cybersecurity arm BDS appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
item.content:encoded:
Reuters was first to report that French defense group Thales is working on a plan to buy the cybersecurity business of IT consultancy group Atos, as part of a $3 billion tie-up that would test the political determination for shoring up France’s digital defenses. Thales, which ranks as Europe’s largest defense electronics company, and its adviser Centerview Partners, have approached several private equity firms, including Bain Capital, to study a joint offer for Atos, which issued two profit warnings in seven months. Any deal involving buyout funds would likely trigger a break-up of Atos and raise political concern ahead of France’s presidential election in April. Shares in Atos jumped 10% on the news, while Thales’ stock was down 3%.

The post Reuters reveals In heated meeting, India seeks tougher action from U.S. tech giants on fake news appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
item.content:encoded:
Reuters exclusively reported that Indian officials have held heated discussions with Google, Twitter and Facebook for not proactively removing what they described as fake news on their platforms, the government’s latest altercation with Big Tech. The officials, from the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, strongly criticized the companies and said their inaction on fake news was forcing the Indian government to order content takedowns, which in turn drew international criticism that authorities were suppressing free expression.

The post Reuters exclusively reports Renault, Nissan, Mitsubishi to unveil 2030 EV plan this week; market reacts appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
item.content:encoded:
Reuters reported exclusively that Renault SA, Nissan Motor Co and Mitsubishi Motors Corp plan to triple their investment to jointly develop electric vehicles (EVs), a mark of deepened cooperation and potentially greater cost savings for the three companies. The three are expected to announce on Thursday a plan to invest more than 20 billion euros ($23 billion) over the next five years on EV development. By 2030, the alliance is expected to come up with more than 30 new battery EVs underpinned by five common platforms, including a new platform for compact EVs designed by Renault.

The post Reuters exclusively reports U.S. examining Alibaba’s cloud unit for national security risks; market reacts appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
item.content:encoded:
Reuters exclusively reported that the Biden administration is reviewing its cloud business to determine whether it poses a risk to U.S. national security. The focus of the probe is on how the company stores U.S. clients’ data – including personal information and intellectual property – and whether the Chinese government could gain access to it. If regulators ultimately decide to block transactions between American firms and Alibaba Cloud, it will damage the bottom line of one of the company’s most promising businesses and deal a blow to reputation of the company as a whole.

item.title: Reuters reveals Jumping on EV wagon represents risky ride for tech pioneer Sony
item.dc:creator: Jaime-Lee Charles

Reuters detailed how, from personal music players to game consoles, Sony Group has often gambled in order to be a pioneer, but […]

The post Reuters reveals Jumping on EV wagon represents risky ride for tech pioneer Sony appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
item.content:encoded:
Reuters detailed how, from personal music players to game consoles, Sony Group has often gambled in order to be a pioneer, but a leap into electric cars could take the risks to a new level for the Japanese consumer tech giant. While investors were wowed when Chief Executive Kenichiro Yoshida told a Las Vegas tech fair the company was setting up Sony Mobility, its stock fell 7% as they contemplated the challenge of delivering EVs packed with sensors, consumer electronics and entertainment offerings. The primary goal of Sony-branded cars, analysts say, is to create an autonomous connected vehicle for services such as car sharing and ride hailing, which could eventually outstrip automobile sales.

item.title: Reuters reveals Islamist attacker’s suspected accomplices used crypto exchange Binance, German police say
item.dc:creator: Jaime-Lee Charles
item.description:
Reuters exclusively reported that two men suspected by Germany of assisting an Islamist gunman, who killed four people in Vienna in 2020, […]

The post Reuters reveals Islamist attacker’s suspected accomplices used crypto exchange Binance, German police say appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
item.content:encoded:
Reuters exclusively reported that two men suspected by Germany of assisting an Islamist gunman, who killed four people in Vienna in 2020, used the major cryptocurrency exchange Binance, German federal police said in a confidential letter seeking information from the company. Germany’s Federal Criminal Police Office (BKA) said in the March 2021 letter, seen by Reuters, that were indications that the suspects bought or sold an unspecified amount of cryptocurrency on Binance. The BKA did not give details of the dates, or the number or value of the transactions. In the letter, the German police asked Binance to provide data relating to the pair, including all digital currency transactions. The request was in connection with “potential terrorist attack plans,” according to the letter.

item.title: Reuters reveals Bain Capital nears $2.27 bln deal to buy French IT services firm Inetum
item.dc:creator: Jaime-Lee Charles
item.description:
Reuters broke the news that U.S. buyout fund Bain Capital is in final talks to buy French IT services firm Inetum in […]

The post Reuters reveals Bain Capital nears $2.27 bln deal to buy French IT services firm Inetum appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
item.content:encoded:
Reuters broke the news that U.S. buyout fund Bain Capital is in final talks to buy French IT services firm Inetum in a deal worth about $2.27 billion. The deal would boost Bain’s presence across Europe’s tech sector. The deal will see Inetum – formerly known as Gfi Informatique – returning into private equity hands after being sold to Qatar’s group Mannai Corp in 2016. Bain is putting the finishing touches to the transaction, which could be signed as early as this week and would value the 52-year old French firm at roughly 2 billion euros ($2.27 billion).

item.title: Reuters reveals Myanmar junta backs Telenor unit sale after buyer M1 pairs with local firm
item.dc:creator: Jaime-Lee Charles

Reuters broke the news that Lebanon’s M1 Group will partner with a Myanmar firm to take over Norwegian telco Telenor’s business in […]

The post Reuters reveals Myanmar junta backs Telenor unit sale after buyer M1 pairs with local firm appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
item.content:encoded:
Reuters broke the news that Lebanon’s M1 Group will partner with a Myanmar firm to take over Norwegian telco Telenor’s business in the Southeast Asian country after its military junta sought a local buyer. Telenor, one of the biggest foreign investors in Myanmar, said in July it was selling its operations there to M1 Group for $105 million, retreating from a country that has slid into chaos after a military coup in February last year. Its exit has been mired in difficulties as the junta piles pressure on telecom and internet companies to install surveillance technology and bars senior executives from leaving the country.

For women who assembled iPhones at a Foxconn plant in southern India, crowded dorms without flush toilets and food sometimes crawling with worms were problems to be endured for the paycheck. Reuters took a closer look at the protest that shut down a plant where 17,000 had been working, casting a stark light on living and working conditions at Foxconn, a firm central to Apple’s supply chain.

The post Global tech crackdown appeared first on Reuters News Agency.
item.content:encoded:
Big Tech has enjoyed years of unfettered growth, but now the U.S., EU, China and India have launched unprecedented crackdowns on some of the biggest names in the business. Lawmakers and regulators are going after anti-competitive practices and looking at privacy and security at companies such as Facebook and Apple, Google and Amazon. Reuters is keeping clients and readers ahead on this huge story, delivering comprehensive coverage and, in some cases, even spurring action by lawmakers and corporations.
